answer: I bet he's knocking on your door all the time with questions.

question: Yes. All the time. The last question was whether to use Biz or Clorox to get the grass stains out of Lucy's soccer uniform.
answer: So let's see..he doesn't know math...he can't even wash her clothes. How about puberty? I can only imagine how much insight he'll bring to approaching the sensitive issues of a young girl's development.

question: Mr. Turner, show me a father, any father, who knows how to do that and I'll give them the Parent of the Year award.
answer: And you've had plenty of opportunity to observe fathers, haven't you?

question: I said that's enough! I will not allow it! Overruled! Overruled!!
answer: Thank you again, Annie. You were truly extraordinary.

question: Extraordinary. Truly extraordinary.
answer: Okay okay okay okay. Well, Sam has his big day on the stand tomorrow and we need to work a little bit so that he's as effective as you were.

question: Effective. Very effective.
answer: On a Porsche, the, uh, the door handle is a little hidden by that thingamajig, so if you're having a hard time finding it I'll just --

question: Good, fine, Sam? Annie's ready. Okay okay okay okay. We'll work in the library. It's down the hall and to the left. Hey, Danny. Where's your father?
answer: Guess.

question: I don't want to guess. Where is he? I told you I don't want to guess.
answer: Well where was he last night?

question: Working late.
answer: There you guessed it.

question: He said he was working late?
answer: That's what he said.

question: Well who did he say was taking care of you?
answer: You. But you said you were working late.

question: I am working late.
answer: Then go work.

question: How was your day?
answer: You have to work. Go work.

question: "Turtles in the half-shell, turtle power!" Rita! Come this is the best part. You eat too fast. Come watch the movie.
answer: It's getting late. We have to get to work. This is my husband's. He won't notice. He's got ten more just like it. Try it on.

question: Bad?
answer: No. Very, very good. But your tie's crooked. Cross over once. Loop it around on the inside of your neck. Slide the other side through the loop, then tighten. Okay okay okay okay. Our strategy is that we're aggressively pursuing a support system. I'm going to ask you h ow are you prepared to help Lucy in school?

question: Let me see let me see let me see.
answer: Sam! I told you you have to stop that! It makes you look stupid! Okay okay okay. Try again. You say you will find her a tutor. Then I say, "How will you pay for it?"

question: Could you slow down? Why do you eat so fast?
answer: We've gone over this a million times. You've found a free tutoring service for her at the YMCA.

question: But I didn't. You did.
answer: Can't you grasp the concept of manipulating the truth? Not lying. Just a little tweak here and there.

question: No...You're so lucky. You get to play with Danny all the time.
answer: He doesn't want to play with me.

question: Yes he does. He does he does. He thinks you don't want to.
answer: Oh that's ridiculous of course I want to.

question: Tweak, tweak.
answer: I drove around after work yesterday 'til 9:30 looking for a goddman razor scooter!

question: Tweak, squeak, peek peek...
answer: Okay, why did you harass that young boy at your home?

question: You know I didn't harass him, Rita. You know that, you know that!
answer: Sam, I'm pretending to be Mr. Turner, remember? Okay?

question: Oh yeah yeah yeah yeah. I didn't harass him, Mr. Turner. Mr. Turner - You don't look like him.
answer: That's a blessing.

question: You're so much prettier.
answer: Thank you. Now. What makes you think you can take care of a woman - I mean a young child - when you have a hard time taking care of yourself? But who are you kidding? Isn't Lucy already smarter than you?

question: In some ways. But in other ways, she's not, I think.
answer: You think?

question: I think.
answer: Sam. You've got to be firm on this.

question: I think in other ways I'm smarter than her. Smarter than you are, Mr. Turner. In fact, in some ways I'm smarter than you, Judge McNeilly.
answer: Whoa! Bring it down.

question: What parent doesn't want more for their child? To be more than the sum of the parts of the whole of them.
answer: Yeah yeah yeah, but it's one thing for a little girl to love her daddy when she's a baby, but once she loses respect for you, what will you do?

question: I won't let that happen. I won't.
answer: How can you say that?

question: Respect is not just about how smart someone is. Smart is not just about how smart someone is.
answer: But what about Lucy? Aren't you being selfish? Doesn't she deserve a better life? Don't you think she's just pretending she's happy to not hurt your feelings?

question: Lucy is happy! We have fun! We go to Denny's, we go to video night. I know how to love her. I know I'm not going to able to go to law school and learn how to be a mean person, but I know how to love. I know how to be her father, Mr. Turner!
answer: I know you do, Sam. I know you do.

question: You look great, Sam. What time do you have to be in court?
answer: Half day, half day. I take the stand at two.

question: Okay, we need two grande cappucinos, non fat.
answer: Sprinkles or Cinnamon? Americano, Americano, not a latte. I'm going to be late! I'm going to be late!

question: I'll call a taxi.
answer: No, no, I can't wait. I can't wait. I've got to go right now.

question: How will you be able to pay for private tutoring?
answer: There's a free program at the YMCA. Lucy can go there.

question: But don't you ever think it would be better for Lucy if she lived with a permanent foster family and you could visit whenever you wanted?
answer: The Fosters don't know her. Why can't she live with me and they can come visit if they want to. I'm firm on this. And I'm getting firmer. Lucy belongs with me.

question: Why?
answer: Paul wrote the first part of the song "Michelle". He said to John, "Where do I go from here?" John had been listening to Nina Simone. There was a line in it that went something like, "I love you, I love you, I love you..." They put that into the song. It wouldn't be the same song without that. It made the song complete. That's why the whole world cried when they broke up on April 10, 1970.

question: When you were Lucy's age, were you living at home?
answer: No.

question: Were you living with your mother and father?
answer: No.

question: Well then where were you living?
answer: In an institution.

question: So your parents put you in an institution?
answer: Only after my mom got sick.

question: What about your father? Where was he?
answer: Gone with the wind when Sam was born.

question: So, you weren't raised by your mother?
answer: I saw her I saw her.

question: When?
answer: Christmas, Easter and my birthday.

question: Oh, once a year on your birthday. So in a way, the people at the institution were your parents. Were they nice to you?
answer: Some yes. Some on. Some yes.

question: Did they hit you?
answer: Sometimes. Sometimes they did sometimes.

question: Let me rephrase that, strong-armed. So what role model do you call upon as a father when you're parenting Lucy? The head of the institution? The Principal the warden?
answer: No. Not Mr. Whitehead. Not him.

question: Then who?
answer: Myself.

question: you have the mental capacity of a seven year old. So you ask yourself, a seven year old -
answer: I am not a seven-year old.

question: How to parent a fellow seven-year old?
answer: Yes. No. What was the question?

question: Right, "Kramer vs. Kramer." Thank you for the commentary, Mr. Bhutto. It's hard to find words isn't it, Mr. Dawson. It's confusing. It's confusing to know what to say to Lucy half the time, isn't it?
answer: No, yes, no.

question: No what?
answer: Let me see let me see let me see.

question: You don't know what?
answer: Yes.

question: You gave him the wrong address! You're hiding me from him! You're going to send me away now, aren't you?
answer: No. Oh, he must've forgotten to put the gift in. You know, this wall really needs something special on it.

question: What's the longest any one of those kids stayed with you?
answer: Megan stayed a little over a year.

question: Sam it's me! Open up! I don't have time for this! You were supposed to show up for your first evaluation. And I leave work early to get there and where the hell are you?! Open the door! Sam! Open the goddamn door! Alright. If you don't care enough to open the goddamn door I'm outta here! I've ruined my practice, I've alienated my colleagues - I sent my kid off on a fishing trip with his father so I could work with you and you won't open your goddman door for me?! Fine! THAT'S IT! I've had enough! Sam, it's Rita. Can I come in?
answer: No room. No room.

question: Hey. I lived in the East Village. I don't need a lot of room.
answer: Sam makes life too hard. Sam makes life too hard on everyone.

question: Sam, I can go at least nine more rounds. But you gotta let me in. Please Sam. Please. Thank you. Now I can see your kind eyes...George told me you needed a break from work.
answer: I don't want to work there anymore. Too many people.

question: Maybe we could find you a quieter job. Because remember one of the judges conditions is you have to earn more money; you've got to keep earning more money for when we get you Lucy back.
answer: Lucy doesn't need me anymore. She has a new family. She doesn't need me anymore.

question: Is that what she said?
answer: She didn't have to say it. I may be stupid, but I know. I know.

question: Well that's the first stupid thing I've ever heard you say. Sam, Sam you can get her back. The court favors reunification. The only thing that can block you is if the foster family petitions to adopt. And from what I've heard, Lucy's making their life miserable - that's our girl. Sam, fight for her.
answer: I tried. I tried.

question: Try harder.
answer: You don't know. You don't know.

question: I don't know?
answer: You don't know what it is to try and try and never get there. You were born perfect, perfect.

question: Is that right? Everyone else is perfect but only Sam feels loss and pain?
answer: That's right. People like you don't know.

question: People like me?
answer: People like you don't know, don't know what hurt feels like, people like you don't feel, don't feel anything.

question: You think you got the market cornered on human suffering? Well let me tell you something about "People like me." People like me feel little and lost and ugly and dispensable. People like me have perfect husbands screwing someone far more perfect than me and my son, my son hates me, I try too hard and I push and he knows it and I talk in that voice, that voice I promised I'd never use, and I've screamed, I've screamed horrible things to him, a five year-old because he doesn't want to get in the car at the end of a day and he stares at me with such anger and I hate him then. I know I'm failing you, I know I'm disappointing you, I know you deserve better but get in the fucking car! It's like every morning I wake up and fail, and I look around and anybody, anybody can pull it off, but somehow I can't. And I know, I know I have everything, and I'm still miserable and it's pathetic. I know it's pathetic. No matter how hard I try, something about me will never be enough.
answer: You're enough. You're so much more than enough. Lovely Rita...

question: You're enough. You're so much more than enough. Lovely Rita...
answer: You're early.

question: All the lights were green.
answer: There's a reason for the court schedule. You stopped showing up. Lucy has had to rebuild her life.

question: I want her back. I can do it. I know I can.
answer: That's not up to me, but I'm telling you, I will do everything in my power to prevent Lucy from getting hurt again. Whose dogs are these?

question: I never forgot you. I forgot me. I hate you I hate you I hate you! Lucy, I tried to write you a letter last night... Gesundheit, Buster. Buster has a cold. But the letter had too many big words. Pokey, sit. Dear Lucy. Pokey sit. Dear Lucy, I'm sorry that I hurt you. Every moment of the day I thought about you. Lucy in the hammock, Lucy at school. Lucy in the sky...XXOO. Daddy. P.S. I love you, recorded September 11th, the day you took your first step. Napa cabbage, excellent choice. Purple and green, purple and green. Very rich in Vitamin C. Good choice. Very good choice.
answer: Hello, Sam. Mr. Dawson. Sam. Dawson.

question: Hello, lawyer.
answer: Shall we?

question: No. We already did. Don't tell anybody.
answer: Furthermore, my client has found a new job, and is making every effort to find a bigger apartment so that -

question: Here.
answer: Oh, thank you. What a...a lovely barrette, Mr. Dawson. It will look great on Lucy. Who I'm sure you bought it for. Furthermore, so that...there will be more room for Lucy as she grows up.

question: Oh, thank you. What a...a lovely barrette, Mr. Dawson. It will look great on Lucy. Who I'm sure you bought it for. Furthermore, so that...there will be more room for Lucy as she grows up.
answer: All of that is well and good but the fact that Mr. Dawson quite his job, missed his hearing, and did not even show up for his visits with his daughter...

question: The fact that my client went through profound depression is the most natural reaction any parent could have.
answer: But once again he had no idea how his behavior during that depression impacted on his daughter.

question: In these next months, Mr. Dawson will be expanding his support system to include Social Service programs, tutors --
answer: It's too late! The foster family is petitioning the court for sole custody of Lucy and I fully support their request.

question: This is very hard to say. I'm having my dessert here. With Rita. I'm not coming to video night.
answer: Sam - if you want to go...

question: I said no, Rita.
answer: I know, but if you -

question: What? Do you want me to go?
answer: I didn't say that. But do you want to go?

question: Where?
answer: Nevermind.

question: Fine.
answer: Fine. I've got it.

question: I've got it. It's good to chew. You're eating more slowly. Coconut Rhubarb. Sidebar, we need to talk. Sidebar.
answer: Yes we do.

question: I need to get Lucy back. We need, we need - to be professional.
answer: Do you know what that means?

question: When dealing with Starbucks' customers, be friendly but not familiar. I can be your friend.
answer: Thank you, Sam.

question: You need to leave your husband.
answer: Oh, my marriage isn't so bad.

question: 'Life is very short and there's no time for fussing and fighting, my friend.'
answer: It's just...it's just that...I've never lost anything.

question: I live here. This is where I live.
answer: This is where you live? So close to me?

question: I wanted to be close to you. I wanted to be closer. Look at my apartment number. John was born on October 9th. His son was born on October 9th.
answer: John met Yoko on November 9th.

question: His mother lived at 9 Newcastle, Liverpool.
answer: Newcastle. 9 letters. Liverpool - 9 letters...

question: I don't want to spend half my visit with Lucy on the bus getting to Lucy. I don't want to waste one more minute.
answer: Does Buster still have his cold?

question: He's better, much better. Now I'll have one box of mint chocolate cookies.
answer: That'll be three-eighty six.

question: Lucy Lucy. What are you doing?! You could have really hurt yourself. What are you doing?
answer: I couldn't sleep. Daddy, did you know that Warren G. Harding was the twenty ninth President of the United States?

question: No.
answer: Remember - the twenty-ninth President. In case the Judge asks.

question: My husband left this when he moved out.
answer: Oh, lovely Rita, meter maid.

question: Nice place. I worry. I worry sometimes...
answer: You worry you did the wrong thing?

question: I worry that I've gotten more out of this relationship than you.
answer: No no no. I'm the lucky one. I have the lawyer that never loses.

question: That's me...okay, let me see, let me see, let me see. They're going to put Bill and Randy on the stand first and then you.
answer: Them first, then me. They're a nice couple. They have a nice house. She's pretty. She's smart, too. I can tell. The manager of the salad bar is gonna testify, isn't he? That will help us.

question: Absolutely.
answer: Nobody believed that George Harrison could really be a song writer. But he wrote "Here Comes the Sun". John and Paul said it was one of the best songs on ABBEY ROAD.

question: George was always my favorite Beatle.
answer: Lucy's was Paul.

question: She fell asleep on the car ride over. I was gonna turn back and tuck her in to her bed...with the pink canopy...and the quilt I made...But I was afraid she'd wake up at our house... ...and want to come home. I was gonna tell the judge that I could give Lucy the kind of love she never had. But I would be lying.
answer: I hope I hope I hope that you're saying what I think you're saying even though you're not saying it.

question: Goodnight. I'll see you in court. Save me a seat...on your side.
answer: Randy! If I tell you I can't do it alone, will you tell the judge?

question: No.
answer: Promise?

question: Promise...
answer: I've looked and looked for a mother for Lucy. Help, I need someone, help, not just anyone. You're the red in Lucy's painting. Penalty! Rules broken. Penalty, please!
